title: Creatures of the Word: How God‚Äôs Speech Creates, Redeems, and Sustains His People | Michael Horton
description:
Michael Horton explores the profound reality that creation itself‚Äîand the Church‚Äîare spoken into being by God‚Äôs powerful Word. He interacts with scenes from C.S. Lewis‚Äô The Magician‚Äôs Nephew and challenges tendencies to privilege seeing over hearing. Horton highlights the biblical emphasis on hearing and receiving God‚Äôs speech, distinguishing between law and gospel, and examining the Church as the creatura verbi: a community formed not by individual initiative but by the Holy Spirit working through the preached Word of Christ. This presentation is from Theo Global in South Asia.

Dr. Michael S. Horton is Founder and Editor-in-Chief of Sola Media (formerly White Horse Inc), home to Core Christianity, White Horse Inn, Modern Reformation, and Theo Global (formerly Global Theological Initiative). He is the J. Gresham Machen Professor of Systematic Theology and Apologetics at Westminster Seminary California.

title: The Theology of the Chronicles of Narnia
description:
Sophia Holcomb joins Michael Horton, Justin Holcomb, Walter Strickland, and Bob Hiller to explore how C. S. Lewis portrays a theology of creation, sin, redemption, sanctification, and new creation throughout The Chronicles of Narnia. From Aslan‚Äôs creation song and the White Witch‚Äôs curse to Aslan‚Äôs substitutionary death and final restoration in The Last Battle, they trace how Lewis communicates the gospel through his most well-known books.

Read more from Sophia at her Substack: 
https://sophiaholcomb.substack.com/

title: Women, the Image of God, and the Middle East | Grace Al-Zoughbi | Theo Global
description:
Grace Al Zoughbi explores the doctrine of the imago Dei and its implications for women's dignity, identity, and participation within Middle Eastern contexts. Drawing on scripture, theology, and lived experience, she challenges both conceptual and cultural traditions that have diminished women, arguing for their equal bearing of God's image and vital roles and visibility. By examining biblical foundations, New Testament interpretations, and comparative perspectives on veiling and gender, Grace Al Zoughbi invites the church to affirm and re-envision the shared human dignity and value of women, particularly women in the Middle East. This presentation is from Theo Global in the Middle East and North Africa.

Dr. Grace Al Zoughbi is Assistant Professor at Arab Baptist Theological Seminary in Lebanon and Accreditation Officer for the Middle East North Africa Association for Theological Education (MENATE). She is originally from Bethlehem, Palestine. 

00:00 "Imago Dei and Women's Inclusion"
04:17 "Women Reflecting God's Glory"
07:16 Paul, Gender, and Theological Symbolism
14:32 "Paul's Vision of New Humanity"
18:14 "Imago Dei Affirms Women's Role"
21:20 "Women, Theology, and Veiling"
25:42 Women's Voices, Visibility, and Dignity
30:35 "Women's Aspirations and Religious Ideals"
34:55 "Imago Dei: Voice and Mission"
35:59 "Imago Dei: Equality and Inclusion"

title: Predestination might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about predestination? As Reformation Christians, we believe that we're saved not because of anything we've said or done but because God chose to show us in Christ a free mercy we could never deserve. And the wicked are condemned not because God delights in their death, but because in his holy will he has allowed them to suffer the just judgment they deserve. We can't pretend to pry into God's hidden wisdom; we can only look to Jesus and his perfect work, finding our personal assurance of God's fatherly goodness in him.

üìñ Isaiah 42:1; Proverbs 16:4; John 6:37‚Äì39, 15:16; Acts 13:48; Romans 8:29‚Äì30, 33‚Äì34, 9:22‚Äì23; Ephesians 1:4‚Äì5; 2 Timothy 1:9; 1 Peter 2:8; Revelation 13:8 #short

title: African vs. Western understanding of the self
description: Watch the full presentation from Theo Global East Africa: https://youtu.be/1Y5alx4shBE #short

title: What is Man? African Traditional Religions, Christianity, & Hebrews 2 | Abeneazer Urga | Theo Global
description:
Dr. Abeneazer Urga (Ethiopia) examines the conception of humanity in African Traditional Religions (ATRs), contrasting their anthropocentric worldview with the biblical, theocentric emphasis found in Hebrews 2. Through critical engagement with African anthropology, Western philosophy, and Christian theology, Abeneazer highlights both the strengths and shortcomings of ATRs‚Äîparticularly their focus on community, Ubuntu, and the nature of humanity as both physical and spiritual. This presentation is from Theo Global East Africa.

PROPHET, PRIEST, AND KING - https://solamedia.org/theologytogether/ 
Get your copy of the first release of Theology Together, a five-volume theology series created in partnership with Zondervan featuring leading theologians from across Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East.  

Abeneazer G. Urga (PhD, Columbia International University) lectures in biblical studies at Evangelical Theological College in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and is an adjunct professor at Columbia International University and Ethiopian Graduate School of Theology. His most recent book is Intercession of Jesus in Hebrews (Mohr Siebeck, 2023).

06:40 "Anthropocentrism in African Religions"
09:11 "Man as Physical and Spiritual"
13:15 "Humanity in African Perspective"
17:03 "Ubuntu, Sin, and Community Ethics"

28:27 "Divine Reconciliation and Human Worth"
31:06 "Christ's Humiliation and Exaltation"
35:39 Sin: Divine Relationship Central Focus
38:39 "God-Centered Corrective to ATR"

title: God's sovereignty might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about God‚Äôs sovereignty? As Christians, we believe that God rules all things in almighty wisdom and power‚Äîwhether creation, providence, redemption, or judgment. This sovereign rule doesn‚Äôt make God a tyrant, and it doesn‚Äôt make us robots. Rather than the author of sin, God is the true King, the free and faithful source of all goodness, justice, and grace for sinners.

title: Man's Need for Salvation: Engaging Apocalyptic Paul | Sherif Fahim | Theo Global
description:
Dr. Sherif Fahim (Egypt) considers the relation of theological anthropology to soteriology in presenting and assessing the anthropology of the Apocalyptic Paul school of thought. 

He examines the influential apocalyptic perspective in 20th-century New Testament scholarship, contrasting the existential emphasis of Rudolf Bultmann with the cosmic, liberation-focused theology of Ernst K√§semann and others. The video traces how apocalyptic readings view Paul‚Äôs anthropology, sin, and salvation, highlighting liberation from cosmic powers rather than individual guilt, and evaluates leading figures such as Christian Becker, Beverly Gaventa, and Douglas Campbell.¬†

Fahim critically assesses the strengths and limitations of the apocalyptic school, especially its diminished focus on the forensic and penal dimensions of Christ‚Äôs atonement, and argues for an integrated understanding that upholds both cosmic liberation and the foundational, substitutionary work of Christ. This presentation is from Theo Global Middle East.

PROPHET, PRIEST, AND KING - https://solamedia.org/theologytogether/ 
Get your copy of the first release of Theology Together, a five-volume theology series created in partnership with Zondervan featuring leading theologians from across Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East.  

Dr. SHERIF A. FAHIM is Professor and New Testament Chair at Alexandria School of Theology and the General Director of El-Soora Ministries in Egypt. He earned his PhD in Biblical Studies from Puritan Reformed Theological Seminary, having written his dissertation on Paul‚Äôs teaching on sanctification in Romans 6.

title: Reformers or Revolutionaries? Why the Church Needed the Reformation
description:
Michael Horton, Gavin Ortlund, and Jordan B. Cooper discuss whether the Reformers were true reformers, or radical revolutionaries who broke away from the church. What was the historical context of the Reformation? Were the Reformers justified in their calls for change and in their early doctrinal arguments?

DEFENDING THE REFORMATION is a 6 part series bringing together Gavin Ortlund, Jordan Cooper, and Michael Horton to address some of the most prominent criticisms of the Reformation and key Protestant doctrines. Were the Reformers true reformers or radical revolutionaries? Does Sola Scriptura undermine church tradition? Is Sola Fide merely a product of nominalism? Together, these Protestant theologians examine the historical context, theological depth, and biblical fidelity of the Reformation. Subscribe to each channel to follow the whole series:
@solamediaorg 
‚Å®@TruthUnites 
@DrJordanBCooper

12:30 Was the church united before the Reformation?

title: 5 Essential Truths for Christians Engaging with Atheists
description:
If you're a Christian deeply invested in theology and apologetics, you‚Äôve probably encountered atheism‚Äîwhether in personal conversations, online debates, or modern culture at large. But too often, Christians assume atheism is all about reason and evidence. And we assume zealous atheism is as popular as it once was. The reality is far more complex‚Äîand far more human.

In this video, theologian Brannon Ellis¬†walks through¬†five essential truths every Christian should understand when engaging with atheism or atheists today.

From the rise and fall of the ‚ÄúNew Atheism‚Äù movement to the deeper heart issues that drive unbelief (both theoretical and practical), we‚Äôll explore why atheism isn‚Äôt just a rational position. It‚Äôs a belief system built on borrowed capital, a heart condition that only the gospel can heal.

PARTNER WITH US - https://solamedia.org/partner/?sc=AS2502VY
When you become a partner today, you'll receive two remarkable books as our thanks:

title: Is the image of God still present in fallen and depraved humanity?
description:
At Theo Global South Asia, Dr. Wilson Jeremiah explores Herman Bavinck‚Äôs work on the image of God and common grace.

https://youtu.be/Ft2L9m6vN_U
 #short

title: Herman Bavinck‚Äôs Trinitarian Approach to the Image of God and Common Grace¬†| Dr. Wilson Jeremiah
description:
Dr. Wilson Jeremiah (Indonesia) introduces the theology of Herman Bavinck with a focus on the metaphysics of the image of God (imago Dei) and common grace, exploring how Bavinck‚Äôs Trinitarian framework enriches our understanding of humanity.¬†

Jeremiah unpacks Bavinck‚Äôs conviction that the imago Dei is best understood not only in Christological but also in pneumatological and Trinitarian terms‚Äîboth individually and collectively, and from an eschatological perspective. He highlights how this approach allows for a fuller appreciation of the body, integrates traditional categories of the image (structural, functional, relational), and clarifies the role of the Holy Spirit in preserving God‚Äôs image‚Äîeven in fallen humanity.
¬†
Jeremiah concludes by considering how Bavinck‚Äôs theology of participation connects the doctrines of the image, common grace, and deification, offering promising insights for Reformed and global theological discussion. This presentation is from Theo Global in South Asia.

PROPHET, PRIEST, AND KING - https://solamedia.org/theologytogether/ 
Get your copy of the first release of Theology Together, a five-volume theology series created in partnership with Zondervan featuring leading theologians from across Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East.

06:11 Human as God's Very Image
07:44 Humanity as God's Image
10:47 Christ's Role in Creation
17:17 Divine Unity and Human Differentiation
20:21 Trinitarian Image in Humanity
23:01 Mystical Union with God
27:24 God's Common Grace Explained
30:55 Bavinck's Holistic Imago Dei
34:12 Eschatology, Image, and Deification
37:21 Deification and Imago Dei

THEO GLOBAL¬†
Theo Global annual symposiums gather brothers and sisters who teach theology in more than 70 seminaries and Bible colleges around the world. Our annual events include South Asia, East Africa, and the Middle East. We are working to expand to Southeast Asia and Latin America in the near future.

title: Atheism might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about atheism? As Christians, we believe that there are actually two kinds of atheists: "theoretical" atheists, who appeal to reason and evidence to justify their unbelief, and "practical" atheists, who simply live as if God isn't there or is irrelevant to our lives. Practical atheism is far more common‚Äîit's found among the spiritual but not religious and even among professing Christians. Being an atheist doesn't necessarily make you a worse person than someone else, but before the judgment seat of God, all stand guilty apart from the gift of right standing in Christ received only by trusting in him. Whether we struggle with theoretical or practical atheism, Jesus is the only one who can satisfy our souls.

üìñ Job 21:14‚Äì15; Psalm 10:4, 14:1, 53:1; Zephaniah 1:12; Luke 12:16‚Äì21; Acts 17:22‚Äì31; Romans 1:18‚Äì23; Titus 1:16 #short

title: Rebellion, Despair, and the Cross | Michael Horton, Jim Davis, Gretchen Ronnevik and Justin Holcomb
description:
How should we share the grace and truth of Jesus with sinners and sufferers in our day to day life and ministry? Join the main speakers of Sola's Binding the Broken conference for this honest and intimate (and often hilarious) Q&A.

00:00 "How do you counsel those struggling with assurance to keep their eyes on Jesus rather than the ups and downs of experience?" Michael Horton answers
01:52 Jim Davis answers
 03:11 Horton follows up
05:14 "In what ways have you seen music show the grace and truth of Jesus to sinners and sufferers, and what's your personal go-to Christian music?" Gretchen Ronnevik answers 
06:52 Justin Holcomb answers
07:39 Jim Davis answers
08:58 Horton answers
11:40 Holcomb follows up to tease Horton
12:02 "What's the best book you could recommend for Christians by a non-Christian?" Horton teases Holcomb
12:29 Holcomb answers
14:26 Horton answers
15:41 "How do I discern when a loss of desire for God is hopelessness, and when is it rebellion?" Ronnevik answers
17:48 Davis answers
19:45 Holcomb answers
22:10 Horton answers
25:33 "How do you do the tricky work of ministering to people who either don't think (or won't admit) they're broken, or else due to social pressure or stigma are ashamed to admit their brokenness?" Ronnevik answers
28:20 Davis answers
30:25 Holcomb answers
35:40 "How has the hope of Jesus' return and the age to come helped you to minister to sinners and sufferers?" Horton answers
39:09 Holcomb answers
39:40 Davis responds
42:50 Davis follows up with a funny story
43:21 Ronnevik answers

A PLACE FOR WEAKNESS - https://solamedia.org/offers/aplaceforweakness/
Weakness isn‚Äôt a flaw. It‚Äôs where hope begins. In¬†A Place for Weakness, Michael Horton shows how the cross and resurrection of Christ don‚Äôt just explain suffering‚Äîthey overcome it.

BINDING THE BROKEN 
We're all sinners and sufferers in need of grace and truth. At this two-day Sola conference in Orlando, keynote speakers Michael Horton, Justin Holcomb, Gretchen Ronnevik, and Jim Davis led us in exploring how Jesus uniquely brings insight and healing to people like you and me. Mining the rich resources of the Reformation, our speakers pointed us to the grace and truth that only Christ can offer to broken people in a fractured world. In these messages, you'll be reminded that Jesus ministers to us so that, in turn, we'll be equipped by him to do the same for others.

title: Self-control might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about self-control? As Christians, we believe that self control is power exercised over ourselves‚Äîour thoughts, desires, feelings, and deeds‚Äîby the power of God's Spirit. Self-control makes us sober and disciplined, but that doesn't mean we're emotionless or refuse to enjoy the legitimate pleasures of life as gifts from God. Instead, we strive to live all of life by grace in gratitude to God and for his glory.

üìñ Proverbs 16:32, 25:28; Isaiah 53:7; Acts 24:25; Galatians 5:23; 1 Corinthians 7:9, 9:25; 1 Thessalonians 5:6, 8; 1 Timothy 3:2; Titus 1:8, 2:2, 5; Hebrews 4:15; 1 Peter 1:13, 5:8; 2 Peter 1:6 #short

title: What does it mean to be made in the image of God?
description:
Dr. Edmund Fong tackles this big question by explaining that to be created imago Dei is to be created imago Christi‚Äîmade in the image of Christ. This presentation is from Theo Global Southeast Asia.

https://youtu.be/EvX5Ti4uEsE
 #short

title: To Be Created Imago Dei Is To Be Created Imago Christi | Dr. Edmund Fong | Theo Global
description:
Edmund Fong (Singapore) investigates the theological depths of what it means for humanity to be created in the image of God (imago Dei), arguing for a distinctively Christ-centered (christological) perspective that sees the image of God most fully revealed in Jesus Christ. Surveying historical interpretations from the early church through Reformation thought, Fong draws on figures like Irenaeus, Athanasius, Augustine, and John Calvin to show how understanding imago Dei as imago Christi clarifies the unique dignity and calling of humanity within creation. He explores and critiques major views‚Äîultimately contending that only by looking to Christ can we grasp the fullness of what it means to be human. This presentation is from Theo Global in South Asia.

Rev. Dr. Edmund Fong is Academic Dean and Lecturer in Systematic Theology, Biblical Hermeneutics and Presbyterianism at Trinity Theological College, Singapore. He is also an ordained Presbyterian Minister with The Presbyterian Church in Singapore.¬†

00:00 Christological Imago Dei Analysis
04:07 Views on the Image of God
07:49 "Christ as Human Archetype"
11:48 "Christological Imago Dei Pathways"
15:07 Patristic Perspectives on Imago Dei
20:12 Augustine's View on Christ's Divinity
23:51 Calvin's View on Eternal Mediator
25:42 Calvin's Christology and Supralapsarianism
29:18 Christological Imago Dei in Redemption
33:10 Christ-Centered Image of God
37:16 Jesus: Divine Human Archetype

title: God's Grace in Exile | Jim Davis on Acts 11:19-30
description:
A PLACE FOR WEAKNESS - https://solamedia.org/offers/aplaceforweakness/
Weakness isn‚Äôt a flaw. It‚Äôs where hope begins. In A Place for Weakness, Michael Horton shows how the cross and resurrection of Christ don‚Äôt just explain suffering‚Äîthey overcome it.

In this message from Jim Davis at Sola‚Äôs Binding the Broken conference, Davis shares how the church‚Äîand even Christians hurt by the church‚Äîare joined to an unshakable assembly: the Kingdom of God. While we may be exiles, sojourning away from our true home, we are nevertheless being sanctified, strengthened, and grown. 

BINDING THE BROKEN 
We're all sinners and sufferers in need of grace and truth. At this two-day Sola conference in Orlando, keynote speakers Michael Horton, Justin Holcomb, Gretchen Ronnevik, and Jim Davis led us in exploring how Jesus uniquely brings insight and healing to people like you and me. Mining the rich resources of the Reformation, our speakers pointed us to the grace and truth that only Christ can offer to broken people in a fractured world. In these messages, you'll be reminded that Jesus ministers to us so that, in turn, we'll be equipped by him to do the same for others.

title: Transhumanism, anti-humanism, and Christianity
description:

https://youtu.be/gYHy6LODRCA
 #short

title: What Are We Made For? Eschatological Anthropology | Michael Horton | Theo Global
description:
Michael Horton identifies and breaks down how transhumanist dreams of uploading our minds to the cloud with technological advances echo ancient ideas about what it means to be human. Namely, they share a common Platonic goal of escaping the limitations of the body.¬†Horton contrasts this with biblical Christianity‚Äôs concept of humanity as the ‚Äúimage of God‚Äù and offers a much different view of human dignity, the problem of evil, and the promise of deification. This presentation was given at Theo Global South Asia 2025.¬†

Michael S. Horton is Founder and Editor-in-Chief of Sola Media is the J. Gresham Machen Professor of Systematic Theology and Apologetics at Westminster Seminary California.

PROPHET, PRIEST, AND KING - https://solamedia.org/theologytogether/

title: Gentleness might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about gentleness? As Christians, we believe that gentleness is what meekness (or humility) looks like in action. It's not weak or waffling, but gentle strength. For Jesus, humility was voluntary. For us, it's necessary. But even for Jesus, humility came before exaltation. Why should we expect our lives to look any different? But with him, and in him, our suffering will also lead through grace to glory.

title: Faithfulness might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about faithfulness? As Christians, we believe that faithfulness first belongs to God before it belongs to us. He's faithful in demonstrating his own integrity, especially in keeping his promises to be both just and the justifier of those who trust in Jesus. Even when we're faithless, Paul says, "God remains faithful, because he cannot deny himself." And the more we experience his faithfulness, the more we by his grace grow in faithfulness toward him and one another.

title: Goodness might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about goodness? As Christians, we believe that goodness is wholeness and satisfaction that comes from the very life of God: the free generosity of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit overflowing in blessing toward all God's creatures. This goodness is especially displayed in undeserved grace toward the Father's beloved sons and daughters, saved not by our own good works but for good works flowing from hearts full of faith and gratitude.

üìñ Genesis 1:31; Psalm 34:8, 100:5, 119:71; Isaiah 64:6; Matthew 6:25‚Äì34; Romans 3:10‚Äì12, 8:28, 32; Ephesians 5:9; Hebrews 12:10‚Äì11 #short

title: Kindness might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about kindness? As Christians, we believe that being kind is far more than being nice or likable. It's far deeper than being affirming or tolerant. Kindness is treating others with dignity and respect, blessing them even though they don't deserve it. Kindness is the opposite of prideful and argumentative self-serving. Christians are kind because God's undeserved kindness toward us has led us to repentance.
¬†
üìñ Proverbs 11:17; Micah 6:8; Luke 1:72, 6:35; Romans 2:4; Ephesians 4:32; Colossians 3:12; 2 Timothy 2:24; Titus 3:1‚Äì11 #short

title: The Theological Anthropology of Paul in Colossians 3:1-17 | Sofanit T. Abebe | Theo Global
description:
Dr. Sofanit Abebe explores how the image of God, though marred by sin, is tangibly restored through union with Christ. She articulates Paul‚Äôs distinctive vision of personhood‚Äînot as autonomous individuals, but as selves shaped through relationship either with sin and death or with the indwelling Christ. This presentation highlights how, for Paul, moral transformation and the renewal of the imago Dei are accomplished not by human willpower but through Christ‚Äôs indwelling presence‚Äîcreating a new identity that transcends ethnic, economic, and social constructs.¬†
This presentation was given at Theo Global East Africa.¬†

Sofanit T. Abebe is a Tutor in New Testament and Lead Tutor for the PhD track for Theological Educators at Trinity College, Bristol.

title: Patience might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about patience? As Christians, we believe that patience isn't a personality trait but a gift of the Holy Spirit's grace, empowering us to wait with hope and confidence for his will to be done in his timing. While patience isn't unfeeling and fearful, it's certainly quick to listen and slow to speak, quick to repent and quick to forgive.¬†

title: Peace might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about peace? As Christians, we believe that peace is the gift of reconciliation with God and others in Jesus that leads to true rest, wholeness, and flourishing. Peace is more than an absence of conflict or anxiety‚Äîit's a life of lasting contentment with God and others that begins with forgiveness in this life and will bear its full fruit in the surpassing peace of the life to come.

title: "To Be Thy Cure" | Justin Holcomb on Christ's work for you
description:
Justin Holcomb explains how the redemptive works of Christ‚Äîhis incarnation, resurrection, and the sending of the Spirit‚Äînot only break the power of sin objectively, but are done for us personally.

Weakness isn‚Äôt a flaw. It‚Äôs where hope begins. In¬†A Place for Weakness, Michael Horton shows how the cross and resurrection of Christ don‚Äôt just explain suffering‚Äîthey overcome it.

BINDING THE BROKEN 
We're all sinners and sufferers in need of grace and truth. At this two-day Sola conference in Orlando, keynote speakers Michael Horton, Justin Holcomb, Gretchen Ronnevik, and Jim Davis led us in exploring how Jesus uniquely brings insight and healing to people like you and me. Mining the rich resources of the Reformation, our speakers pointed us to the grace and truth that only Christ can offer to broken people in a fractured world. In these messages, you'll be reminded that Jesus ministers to us so that, in turn, we'll be equipped by him to do the same for others.

title: Joy might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about joy? As Christians, we believe that joy is deep and lasting happiness, delight, and satisfaction in God and his good gifts, especially the gift of enjoying life with him and one another in Jesus Christ. This joy isn't based in our feelings or circumstances, but in the boundlessly happy life of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. In Jesus, we will know joy at the end because it has always been in God since the beginning.

üìñ  Psalm 16:11, 37:4; Nehemiah 8:10; John 15:11; Romans 5:1‚Äì2; 2 Corinthians 6:10; Philippians 4:4 #short

title: What is the Passive Obedience of Christ?
description: Dr. Brannon Ellis explains. Full video here: https://youtu.be/HN5rLtuj7dI #short

title: The Great Exchange: The Good News of Jesus' Active and Passive Obedience
description:
Obedience is pleasing to God. But my life and your life have more or less been exercises in disobedience: failing to keep God's law, falling short, missing the mark of loving him as he deserves and loving our neighbors as he commands.
So how is obedience not only good, but even good news? The answer is that it's not our obedience that's good news. It's Jesus' obedience. And it's the best possible news.
In this episode of The Christian Mind, we explore the precious Christian truth of Jesus' suffering and obedience in our place and for our sake--what the church since ancient times has often called the Great Exchange.
Jesus didn't pay our debts just to place us on never ending parole. He didn't come to rescue us from punishment only to leave us to wander ceaselessly through the wilderness. Jesus sets the captives free. He brings us home.

0:00 The Passive Obedience of Christ
5:34 Passive Obedience isn't enough
7:57 The Active Obedience of Christ

title: Love might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about love? As Christians, we believe that "we love because he first loved us" (1 John 4:19). Love's source is the intimate communion of the Trinity. God's gift of love leads to salvation in Jesus, which in turn leads to us giving ourselves in wholehearted personal commitment to God and others. Jesus says this is the summary of the law. Jesus kept that law perfectly for our sake and as our Savior now pours his Spirit into our hearts so that by his grace we can begin to love like he does.

üìñ Matthew 22:34‚Äì40; Romans 5:8, 13:8‚Äì10; 1 John 4:7‚Äì12; 2 John 6 #short

title: The Image of God, in Light of Christ | A Conversation with Edmund Fong | Theo Global
description:
What does it mean to be created in the image of God?¬† If Jesus Christ is the true Image of God, what does that mean for us? Michael Horton and Adam Smith sit down at Theo Global Southeast Asia with Dr. Edmund Fong  (Singapore) to discuss a Christocentric approach to understanding the Image of God. 

REV. DR. EDMUND FONG is a lecturer in Systematic Theology, Biblical Hermeneutics and Presbyterianism at Trinity Theological College, Singapore. He is also an ordained Presbyterian Minister with The Presbyterian Church in Singapore.

THEO GLOBAL JOURNAL
Get your copy of the Theo Global Journal, including  papers from the 2024 symposiums
https://solamedia.org/tgjournal/

title: Sinners, Come Boldly to the Throne of Grace | Michael Horton on Jesus as our sympathetic high priest
description:
"God may pity me, but he could never understand me." Don't we often feel that way, especially when confronted with the darkest parts of of the human heart--both in ourselves and others? In this moving and pastorally rich message based on Hebrews 4, Michael Horton urges us not to hide ourselves from God but to hide ourselves in God by approaching his throne of grace through our sympathetic high priest, Jesus Christ.

A PLACE FOR WEAKNESS - https://solamedia.org/offers/aplaceforweakness/
Weakness isn‚Äôt a flaw. It‚Äôs where hope begins. In¬†A Place for Weakness, Michael Horton shows how the cross and resurrection of Christ don‚Äôt just explain suffering‚Äîthey overcome it.

BINDING THE BROKEN 
We're all sinners and sufferers in need of grace and truth. At this two-day Sola conference in Orlando, keynote speakers Michael Horton, Justin Holcomb, Gretchen Ronnevik, and Jim Davis led us in exploring how Jesus uniquely brings insight and healing to people like you and me. Mining the rich resources of the Reformation, our speakers pointed us to the grace and truth that only Christ can offer to broken people in a fractured world.

title: Trinitarian Heresies | Justin Holcomb | Theo Global
description:
In this presentation, Dr. Justin Holcomb surveys historical challenges and misunderstandings of the Trinity, explaining what was lost in their concepts. He provides examples and lessons from both today and from history that clarify the doctrine of the Trinity, as well as its centrality and relevance in Christianity. He explores how our understanding of Jesus‚Äô work in salvation closely relates to our understanding of the doctrine of the Trinity.

THEO GLOBAL JOURNAL
Get your copy of the Theo Global Journal, including this presentation and other papers from the 2024 symposiums
https://solamedia.org/tgjournal/

1:00 - Understanding the Trinity matters in our worship¬†
3:15 - I. The Doctrine of the Trinity
4:50 - II. What is Heresy? What is a Hertic?
6:30 - III. Sabellianism - God was one actor, with three masks
9:30 - Sabellianism: Who died on the cross? Who did Jesus pray to?¬†
13:00 - Marcion and Monotheism
15:45 - Orthodox Response: Hippolytus, Tertullian, Origen
16:30 - Modalism‚Äôs significance today and Oneness Pentecostalism
18:30 - Sabellianism undermines Christ‚Äôs Atonement and is wrongly attributed to Christianity by Islam, Mormonism, and Jehovah‚Äôs Witnesses.¬†
20:00 - VI. Arianism - the Son is a lesser being / lesser god than the Father
22:30 - Paul of Samosata - Adoptionism
23:00 - Origen‚Äôs lack of clarity and two streams of thought
24:30 - Looking at Arius‚Äô thought: The Son as the highest creature. There was a time ‚Äúwhen the Son was not.‚Äù
28:15 - The Apostle‚Äôs Creed condemns Arianism
29:25 - Why is this relevant to salvation, Christ‚Äôs mediation, and our worship?
32:15 - The beauty and goodness of Trinitarian worship
34:45 - The doctrine of the Trinity - why does it matter so much? Without it, what do we lose?¬†

description:

title: Sanctification might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about sanctification? As Christians, we believe that God makes us holy by grace through faith. We're both holy now in Jesus and we're growing in holiness as the Holy Spirit enables us to walk faithfully as disciples of Jesus, leading and strengthening us by his word and sacraments as we look to him. Sanctification isn't optional, but it's not a work we achieve; it's a gift we receive.

title: "Our understanding of Christianity cannot be better than our grasp of adoption.‚Äù ‚Äî J. I. Packer
description: For Theo Global, Dr. Vijai Tagore provides a biblical theological reflection and analysis of how the fatherhood of God unfolds in Scripture. Full talk: https://youtu.be/cJPrM2gdTsQ #short

title: The Fatherhood of God | Vijai Tagore | Theo Global
description:
In this presentation, Dr. Vijai Tagore provides a biblical theological reflection and analysis of how the fatherhood of God is unfolding in the Scripture, from the Old Testament and within the New Testament. In recent decades, this has been questioned along with the use of masculine expressions. He concludes that, ‚Äúsince the context of the fatherhood of God in Scripture is covenantal and theological, it does not cease with changing times and cultures. Father is his eternal name.‚Äù¬†

VIJAI SINGH TAGORE is Associate Professor of New Testament and Coordinator for Post-Graduate Studies at Presbyterian Theological Seminary in India. He earned his PhD in New Testament from Christ College in Australia and is an ordained minister in the Reformed Presbyterian Church of India. 

THEO GLOBAL JOURNAL

title: Righteousness might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about righteousness? As Christians, we believe that God is perfectly righteous‚Äîupright and faithful in his character, words, and works. He created us in righteousness to reflect his image, but we rebelled in falsehood and unfaithfulness. Now that path of righteousness is forever closed to us. Our only hope lies in God's righteousness given to us in Jesus, so that God might truly be just and the justifier of those who believe. Now, we possess Christ's righteousness both so that we can be declared righteous (justified) and that we can walk in his faithfulness by grace (sanctified).

JOSEPH BYAMUKAMA (PhD, Ridley College, Melbourne) is the lead pastor at The Fount Church, Kampala, Uganda and the Team Leader at Veracity Fount, a ministry that seeks to equip the Ugandan Church through contextual theological research and resources. Joseph is interested in New Testament Intertextuality, New Testament and African Christologies, Church Planting, and theological training.

title: The Crown of Creation: Humanity and the Image of God | Roundtable Discussion | Theo Global
description:
How do we understand humanity as the ‚Äúcrown of creation‚Äù and as being made in the image of God?¬† How is biblical Christianity‚Äôs understanding of this different from other concepts and world religions?

Theo Global‚Äôs Adam Smith sat down with Dr. Talant Aktanzhanov (Kazakhstan), Dr. Julian Gutierrez (Colombia/USA), and Dr. Michael Horton (USA) to discuss the contours of what it means to be human in light of biblical teaching, and in contrast to alternate views and concepts.¬†

THEO GLOBAL JOURNAL
Get your copy of the Theo Global Journal, including papers from the 2024 symposiums
https://solamedia.org/tgjournal/

0:45 - Introductions
3:50 - What does it mean to be the ‚Äúcrown of creation,‚Äù made in the image of God?
5:40 - Ancient Near East cultures used ‚Äúson‚Äù and ‚Äúimage‚Äù similarly, signifying God‚Äôs representatives.¬†
7:20 -¬† Humanity contrasted in Christianity and Islam¬†
12:25 - God relates to humanity through covenant
13:25 - Humanity contrasted in Christianity, Transhumanism, and Gnosticism
15:20 - Humanity‚Äôs relationship with body and soul
17:25 - Importance of centering our concept of humanity on the doctrine of God and creation
20:20 - Christianity does not seek to discard our humanity, but conforms to Jesus who is the true image of God.
22:00 - Individualism, Self-determination, and Belonging. Assumptions about what it means to be human in different parts of the world
23:40 - Christianity‚Äôs Creator/Creature distinction: We are not God vs becoming gods in Mormonism, and Transhumanism.¬†
28:00 - We must remember to extend the dignity of being the image of God to others


DR MICHAEL S. HORTON is Founder and Editor-in-Chief of Sola Media, the home to Core Christianity, White Horse Inn, Modern Reformation, and Theo Global. He is the J. Gresham Machen Professor of Systematic Theology and Apologetics at Westminster Seminary California.

DR. TALANT AKTANZHANOV is from Almaty, Kazakhstan and serves as a seminary professor.¬†

DR. JULIAN GUTIERREZ is originally from Colombia. He is a professor of systematic theology at Redemption seminary and at CTD Latam in Peru. He serves as Systematic Theology Book Review Editor for Themelios Journal.

ADAM SMITH is the Chief Operating Officer at Sola Media and has led the Theo Global project since 2015. He serves as Managing Editor for Theo Global‚Äôs Theology Together Series and the Theo Global Journal.¬† He is a minister in the Presbyterian Church of America.

title: The cross might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about the cross? As Christians, we believe that the crucifixion of Jesus is simultaneously the lowest act of human rebellion and the highest act of God's redemption. On the cross, the Son of God suffered the curse of sin in our place, bearing our punishment and shame so that we now stand guiltless and forgiven. By his Spirit, the now-risen Jesus enables us to take up our crosses and follow him on the path through suffering to glory.

title: Ross Douthat on major religions and cults

title: How we understand the Trinity determines who we worship

title: The Trinity and the Dangers of Biblicism | Michael Horton | Theo Global
description:
How do we understand the three persons of the Trinity (Father, Son, and Holy Spirit)?¬†What is the controversial ‚Äúeternal subordination of the Son‚Äù view and how should we assess it?

In this presentation, Dr. Michael Horton interacts with biblicism‚Äôs denial of the historical Christian understanding of the Trinity - reflected in the work of Bruce Ware, Wayne Grudem, and John Frame‚Äôs concepts of the eternal subordination of the Son. In this presentation, he shows how these statements and formulations are inconsistent with historical Christian articulations and confessional statements (such as the Nicene Creed).

THEO GLOBAL JOURNAL
Get your copy of the Theo Global Journal, including this presentation and other papers from the 2024 symposiums
https://solamedia.org/tgjournal/

0:45 - The Importance of both Systematic and Biblical Theology
2:40 - Biblicism‚Äôs challenges the doctrine of the Trinity in evangelicalism
6:15 - Jurgen Moltmann and his social doctrine of the Trinity
7:15 - The eternal functional subordination of the Son (Wayne Grudem, Bruce Ware, John Frame) supporting complementarianism
12:40 - Taxis (order) as a patristic concept that does not imply subordination or roles
18:20 - Who we worship is the ultimate taste test.¬†
22:40 - Theologically conservative blurring of the immanent and economic Trinity
26:30 - Problematically extending subordination to the Holy Spirit and to human relationships
34:00 - John 5 - the Son‚Äôs aseity. Ware‚Äôs point is opposite of Augustine
36:15 - John Frame‚Äôs affirmation of eternal subordination of the Son and denial of simplicity, impassibility and immutability
41:00 - Assessing Frame‚Äôs ‚Äúeternal subordination of role‚Äù as similar to Arian concepts
43:00 - Review of orthodox articulations: distinction between ‚Äúeternal and economic‚Äù
44:40 - Importance of orthodoxy in our worship, prayers, and churches

MICHAEL S. HORTON is Founder and Editor-in-Chief of Sola Media, the home to Core Christianity, White Horse Inn, Modern Reformation, and Theo Global. He is the J. Gresham Machen Professor of Systematic Theology and Apologetics at Westminster Seminary California.
This presentation was given at Theo Global South Asia 2024.

title: The atonement might not be what you think it is
description:

As Christians, we believe that Jesus' death on the cross wasn't merely an example or a demonstration of love and justice, but a necessary sacrifice to satisfy the righteous wrath of God against his childrens' rebellion and sin. title: Is everything up to God or up to chance?
description:
‚ÄúChance is blind, but God sees everything. Chance is weak, but God is able. Chance is careless, but God is good.‚Äù

Egyptian theologian Dr. Sherif Fahim of El Soora explores whether God is sovereign or takes risks in giving humans free will. Watch the full talk from Theo Global Middle East: https://youtu.be/1r3VcpFx2dM
 #short

title: Exploring Divine Providence | Sherif A. Fahim | Theo Global
description:
In giving humanity free will, did God take a risk? How does ‚Äúconcurrence‚Äù help us understand the relationship between God‚Äôs sovereignty and human responsibility? How does our understanding of this relate to our understanding of God‚Äôs omnipotence, omniscience, and goodness?¬† These questions are asked and answered throughout the world.¬†
In this presentation, Dr. Sherif Fahim explores and articulates, from the Bible, how creation depends on God not just for its origin, but for continuation, and survival.¬†
History is not guided by purposeless or random forces or without intention. Rather, it is the wise, holy, all powerful, good and righteous God who leads history to an end that he intended from eternity. The biblical doctrine of God's providence provides us with a caring, wise, loving, powerful and all knowing God whose purposes can never be thwarted.

DR. SHERIF A. FAHIM is Professor and New Testament Chair at Alexandria School of Theology and the General Director of El-Soora Ministries in Egypt. He earned his PhD in Biblical Studies from Puritan Reformed Theological Seminary, having written his dissertation on Paul‚Äôs teaching on sanctification in Romans 6.

IN THIS VIDEO
1:00 - God‚Äôs providence defined in contrast to Pantheism and Deism (Francis Turretin)
6:20 - Human Reason and Divine Revelation¬†
11:45 - Two Dangers on Divine Providence: Claiming to know too much (rationalism) or too little (postmodernism). We attend to what God reveals in the Bible.¬†
14:45 - Why is there suffering if God is good? Does God risk?¬†¬†
17:45 - God‚Äôs Attributes: Omniscience
25:40 - God‚Äôs Attributes: Omnipotence
35:55 - God‚Äôs Attributes: Goodness - how could God allow for sin to exist?
38:45 - How could moral evil be consistent with the providential order of an all-good, all-powerful God?
43:20 - ‚ÄúConcurrence‚Äù - God carries out his good will through the free will of humans.¬†
46:45 - We should not dilute God‚Äôs providence, in order to uphold human responsibility
48:00 - Chance is random, blind, weak and careless. God is purposeful, knowing, powerful, wise, and loving.¬†
¬†

title: What does it mean to be made in the image of God?

 #short

title: Reflections of Glory: What It Means to Be Made (and Remade) in the Image of God
description:
Ever wonder what it truly means to be made in God's image? In this episode of The Christian Mind, we explore‚Äîwith the help of the metaphor of photography‚Äîthe Bible's profound teaching about our creation in the image of God. This image is both an identity and a calling, fundamentally shaping our understanding of God, ourselves, and our purpose in the world.

Join us as we delve into:

0:00 INTRODUCTION: How photography gives us a glimpse into how we're made to bear and reflect the image of God
1:03 THE GOD WE IMAGE: Understanding the invisible Trinity and why we're forbidden to create physical images of the Almighty.
3:45 IMAGES OF GOD: How human beings are uniquely designed to reflect God's character and glory as his image-bearers.
5:27 FADED IMAGES: Recognizing our fallen nature and the ways we distort God's reflection.
6:42 THE ORIGINAL IMAGE: Discovering how Jesus, the eternal radiance of God's glory in perfect humanity, restores our image-bearing capacity.
8:37 IMAGES RESTORED: Embracing our calling as renewed image-bearers in Christ to reflect God's love, mercy, and grace to the world.

KEY BIBLE PASSAGES
‚Äî The prohibition against creating images of God (Deuteronomy 4:11‚Äì12, 15‚Äì16).
‚Äî God's desire to make the full spectrum of his character known (Habakkuk 2:14, John 17:3).
‚Äî Humanity's unique creation as God's image-bearers (Genesis 1:26‚Äì27).
‚Äî Jesus as the original and perfect image of God (Hebrews 1:3).
‚Äî Our restored purpose as image-bearers in Christ (1 Peter 2:9).

ADDITIONAL RESOURCES
‚Äî Previous video on the incomprehensibility of God: https://youtu.be/5O8o2RWSgDA?si=QokbFkdHy41oYEMi
‚Äî The Westminster Shorter Catechism: https://opc.org/sc.html

title: Rich theology can be sung and written as poetry, not just as logical statements and declarations.
description:

Dr. Grace Al-Zoughbi, a Palestinian from Bethlehem, at Theo Global‚Äôs 2024 Middle East symposium.  #short

title: Was Mary a theologian?
description: Dr. Grace Al-Zoughbi, a Palestinian scholar from Bethlehem, share her reflection and reading of Mary‚Äôs Magnificat at Theo Global.  #short

title: The wrath of God might not be what you think it is
description:
What's the truth about the wrath of God? As Christians, we believe that wrath is the appropriate stance of the good, holy, righteous, loving God against all that is evil, impure, unjust, and hateful. But God doesn't only exercise wrath; in his mercy, God in Christ drinks the cup of wrath we deserve to share with us the cup of heavenly blessing.

üìñ Romans 1:18‚Äì32, 3:5‚Äì6, 12:19, 13:4; 1 Thessalonians 5:1‚Äì11

 #short

title: Mary's Magnificat is a hymn of hope for the hopeless
description:
Hope in the midst of lament and suffering. Hope for the humble and hungry. 

Dr. Grace Al-Zoughbi, a Palestinian from Bethlehem, shares how Mary and other Middle Eastern women have found and articulated enduring hope in Christ over the centuries at Theo Global‚Äôs 2024 Middle East symposium. 

Watch the full talk on the hymnology of eastern women: https://youtu.be/t-sJou-_loo #short

title: Exploring God‚Äôs Attributes in the Hymnology of Eastern Women | Dr. Grace Al-Zoughbi | Theo Global
description:
Theology is done and proclaimed richly and beautifully in song and poetry, not just in prose and logic.¬†This presentation is an extraordinary survey of historical examples of women and hymnology from the Middle East that have articulated God‚Äôs Attributes - in ways profoundly meaningful in the Middle East and to the church throughout the world.¬†

Dr. GRACE AL-ZOUGHBI ARTEEN is Assistant Professor at Arab Baptist Theological Seminary in Lebanon and Accreditation Officer at Middle East and North Africa Association for Theological Education. She is a Palestinian Christian originally from Bethlehem. She holds a PhD in theology from the London School of Theology. Her doctoral research focused on Arab women in theological education as a contribution to ecclesial understanding of Christianity in the Middle East.

0:00 - Over centuries, hymns were a vehicle for unique theological contributions by women in the Middle East.
2:50 - Examples of eastern women bearing witness to God‚Äôs attributes
5:08 - Origins & overview of the Syriac Church and adoption of its hymnology by the Protestant tradition
7:45 - Mary‚Äôs Magnificat as a biblical example of poetic theology, by a woman, on God‚Äôs attributes
10:35 - Mary‚Äôs emphasis and insights on God‚Äôs striking juxtapositions and faithfulness
14:07 - Mary‚Äôs song is a triumphant song of reversals, in Christ, and particularly relevant to the experience of Christians in the Middle East
14:55 - Juxtaposition and paradox: St. Ephrem (4th C) and women in poetry and hymnology
20:12 - Daughters of the Covenant sang to defeat the heresies of the early centuries, declaring theology
23:00 - Importance of theological contributions from Arab women and the Middle East to the wider Christian tradition
26:45 - Recent example: Mary‚Äôs mournful lament hymn sung by Fairuz
30:58 - Theology is a reaction to God‚Äôs self-revelation, and can be done in song, poetry, and hymns.
33:05 - Theology doesn‚Äôt have to be a treatise or paper, to be profound
33:30 - Need for public singing of theology and for women‚Äôs theological voices in the Middle East and global Protestant church.¬†

¬†

title: Ch 2 - Recreation: Noah and the Flood
description:
Adam and Eve‚Äôs children and grandchildren are no better at obeying than Adam and Eve were! Sin has trampled through the world, leaving it ugly and messy. God is sad to see his creation so broken, so he decides to send a flood to wipe away the sinful world‚Äîbut he has a plan to save his people and keep his promise to send a new Adam!

title: The Self-Revealing and Accommodating God | Justin Holcomb | Theo Global
description:
How can finite creatures understand an infinite God?¬† Can God be fully comprehended and known? Can God be truly known? In this presentation, Justin Holcomb explores and explains how Christian theology can understand God through God‚Äôs accommodation through self-revelation. This presentation was originally given at Theo Global South Asia.¬†

Rev. Dr. Justin Holcomb is a Senior Fellow with Theo Global, professor at the Reformed Theological Seminary, and Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Central Florida. He is the author or editor of more than 20 books on historical theology, abuse, and biblical studies.

0:00 - How can an infinite God be revealed and known?¬†
3:28 - God Transcends Creation. Creator and creature distinction in Western and Eastern Orthodox theology
4:00 - What we can and cannot know; God‚Äôs Essence and God‚Äôs Energies¬†
6:20 - Scripture: Not God‚Äôs essence, but the location and record of God‚Äôs speech
7:00 - John Calvin - God‚Äôs essence is to be adored, but not inquired into
7:35 - God‚Äôs revelation is God‚Äôs condescending ‚Äúaccommodation‚Äù to our limited capacities (Aquinas, Chrysostom, Origen, Augustine, Clement of Alexandria)
9:30 - Finite creatures cannot perfectly know or comprehend the infinite God (Aquinas)
11:28 - John Calvin on God‚Äôs ‚Äúaccommodating‚Äù in revelation
15:30 - John Calvin - theology does not handle what God is, only what God is like in relation to the world
19:40 - The giving of God‚Äôs name, Yahweh: Revelation vs. speculation.
21:45 - Humans can have true knowledge of God through God‚Äôs self-revelation
22:40 - Univocal, equivocal and analogical views
25:20 - Archetypal and ectypal theology. Christian theology rests on God‚Äôs self-revelation
28:12 - We can know God truly, through His speech/revelation, although not fully.

title: The Dogmatic and Apologetic Functions of Divine Simplicity | Dr. Wilson Jeremiah | Theo Global
description:
Is the doctrine of Divine Simplicity merely a philosophical abstraction? How has it been understood and helpfully applied over the centuries of the church in relation to the creator/creation distinction, the Trinity, the Incarnation, and the Atonement? 
In this lecture, Wilson Jeremiah reveals how divine simplicity has been ignored and misunderstood at times, and how it has been critically helpful in understanding God, his attributes, and his works.¬†

Dr. Wilson Jeremiah is a Faculty Lecturer in Theological Studies at SEABS in Malang, Indonesia

0:00 Diagnosing omission, confusion, and objections regarding the doctrine of God‚Äôs simplicity
2:40¬† Why this lack of discussion on divine simplicity? Is the concept not relevant, too abstract, or philosophical?¬†
5:13 Divine simplicity is normative for theology since the church fathers - Richard Muller¬†
6:30 Paper‚Äôs aim is to demonstrate why simplicity is indispensable for the Christian faith and ground doctrines of the Trinity, Incarnation, and Atonement
8:00 Definition, historic affirmations, and biblical support of Divine Simplicity
14:35 Simplicity and the Trinity: Westminster Confession of Faith, Francis Turretin, Jurgen Moltmann
21:50 Simplicity and Jesus‚Äô Incarnation: Do we become God? Do we become part of God? Simplicity guards against pantheism and panentheism
25:30 Turretin‚Äôs use of simplicity in relation to communicatio idiomatum and the hypostatic union of Christ
28:10 Simplicity and the Atonement; The undivided works of the Trinity and challenges to penal substitutionary atonement
35:20 The Apologetic Function of Divine Simplicity: Helpful to Early Christian and Muslim Debates
45:55 Why have people never heard of simplicity?¬†

title: Creation is not what you think it is
description: What's the truth about creation? As Christians, we believe that God created all things from nothing out of his sheer generosity. So while the created order isn't itself divine, that doesn't make it inherently bad. God made all things good. He created us in his image to exercise wise authority over the rest of the earthly creation. Evil is the result of creaturely freedom twisted into rebellion. And salvation is the free gift of God in his Son, the Creator become a creature, to redeem his people and to renew the creation which was subject to corruption because of sin. #short

title: You Are Fully Known: The Surprising Good News of God's Incomprehensibility
description:
"Incomprehensible" probably isn't the first word you think of when reflecting on the gospel. So why do theologians always talk this way about the God of the gospel?

In this video we explore the seeming paradox of a God who is both utterly beyond our comprehension and intimately known in Jesus Christ. We delve into the Christian doctrine of God's incomprehensibility, examining what it means for creatures to know and be known by our Creator. We discuss how our attempts to contain God betray our own rebellious nature, and how the good news of the gospel emerges in the midst of this bad news. 

Discover how God's incomprehensibility actually points to his deep and personal knowledge of¬†us, and how this knowledge offers surprising comfort and hope to those who know God personally in Jesus Christ. Join us as we unpack this profound concept and explore its implications for faith, discipleship, and assurance in the surprisingly good news of God's incomprehensibility.

0:19 The curious relationship between the gospel's availability and God's incomprehensibility
1:21 The classic definition of "comprehend" and the doctrine of God's incomprehensibility
1:46 Creaturely limits aren't inherently bad, but it's not good to try to force God to fit within the limits of our own understanding
2:10 The only way to fit a full balloon (God) into a little jar (our minds) is to take all the air out of it, making God seem manageable but also not very God-like
3:05 An even better analogy for God's incomprehensibility than an air-filled balloon is air itself
3:46 We dare not take too lightly the infinite mystery of the Lord God Almighty
5:05 Being created and limited in our knowledge of God isn't our real problem; our real problem is what we as corrupt sinners do with the knowledge we have
5:43 The surprising good news of God's incomprehensibility begins with the bad news of our inability
6:02 Not only is God uncontainable‚Äîwe're the ones who are contained. This is where the story of God's incomprehensibility starts to shift.
6:40 If we know the incomprehensible God, it must be because he has chosen to make himself known
7:08 As Christians we trust that God's goodness in revealing himself to us isn't just general, but specific and personal. It's saving grace.
7:38 The surprising good news of the incomprehensible God 
8:31 John Calvin: "If we are united to Christ by faith, we possess God"

title: Theology is Essential for Discipleship: A Conversation with KJ Drake
description:
Why is theology crucial for Christian discipleship? In this engaging conversation, Brannon Ellis (Executive Editor of Modern Reformation) sits down with KJ Drake (Associate Professor of Historical Theology at Indianapolis Theological Seminary) to explore the vital connections between the Bible, theology, faith, church life, and everyday Christian living. They discuss:

0:00 Intro¬†
0:32 The Disconnect Between Knowledge and Application
1:52 KJ's Realization about the Importance of Theological Thinking
3:43 The Problem of Separating Doctrines into Disjointed Statements
5:57 Brannon's Conversation with Two Jehovah's Witnesses
6:47 The Church Often Neglects Trinitarian Worship
9:10 The Difference between Knowing about God and Knowing God
10:04 Theology is "Living to God in Christ"
11:55 Doctrines are Tools for Understanding and Living Faithfully
14:11 Theology is Reading the Bible Well
16:12 Grounding Theology in Scripture and Community
16:45 Pride and Over-Specialization are Obstacles to Theological Reasoning

20:24 Past Masters are Models of Theological Reasoning
21:58 The Role of the Sacraments in Theological Reasoning
23:54 The Importance of Continued Study and Reflection
24:49 Opportunities for Theology in a Post-Christian World
27:15 The Real Dangers of Bad Doctrine
28:20 Good Theology Matters for Everyday Life
29:23 True Theology Lasts Forever

Join us to discover how an ever-deeper knowledge of God and his ways is non-negotiable‚Äîboth for growing in being a faithful disciple of Jesus and for fruitfulness in our calling to participate in Jesus' mission of making disciples.

Host: Brannon Ellis
Guest: KJ Drake, Indianapolis Theological Seminary. https://indysem.org

title: Redemption and Repentance: The Story of Bathsheba | White Horse Inn
description:
The story of Uriah‚Äôs wife does not exactly scream Christmas cheer. Yet, as we reflect on the Mothers of Jesus, we cannot overlook that just as Jesus was born in Bethlehem, Matthew traces his lineage back to the town of David. Though sentimentality is absent from Bathsheba‚Äôs story, Michael Horton, Justin Holcomb, Walter Strickland, and Bob Hiller reveal the incredible hope that challenges our cynicism about how God works through his people‚Äîand even their sin‚Äîto fulfill his purposes.

title: Theo Global | Theology By and For a Global Church
description:
Over the last 10 years, Theo Global has gathered theologians and biblical scholars from around the world to engage in the same kind of conversational theology that began with White Horse Inn and Modern Reformation.

Through annual symposiums in a four regions, Theo Global bridges the gap between the West and the majority world, fostering theological collaboration and learning among its leading scholars. As the Lord grows his church, Theo Global helps the theological roots of the church deepen and mature, while also bringing the insights, experience and scholarship from the global church back to the church in the West. We have so much to learn from one another as we do theology together. 

Learn more at https://solamedia.org/theoglobal/

title: How Culture Shapes Our Theology | White Horse Inn

This trip was part of Theo Global's annual efforts to gather leading theologians and biblical scholars from across the Middle East and then from East Africa to do theology together‚Äîso that the theological roots of the global church can grow strong.

title: The Dangers of the New Apostolic Reformation with Holly Pivec & R. Douglas Geivett
description:
Is the New Apostolic Reformation a reckless movement? Modern Reformation Executive Editor Brannon Ellis sits down with experts Holly Pivec & R. Douglas Geivett to talk about the dangers of the New Apostolic Reformation (NAR), which is one of the fastest growing movements in American Christianity.

LEARN MORE:
You can read more about the NAR in a recent edition, "This Isn't The Reformation You're Looking For" - https://www.modernreformation.org/resources/issues/this-isnt-the-reformation-youre-looking-for

Over on our sister podcast White Horse Inn, the hosts covered this topic as part of their series "Shamans in the Church" - https://whitehorseinn.org/resource-library/shows/the-new-old-apostolic-reformation/

0:00-2:11 This Isn't the Reformation You're Looking For

title: Christianity & the Arts
description:
*NEW SERIES STARTS TOMORROW* Meet Carla Meberg, a special friend of White Horse Inn. We sat down with her to talk about her passion for creativity and the arts. In the coming days, we'll share more from Carla including a special art piece she has created for you, our listeners. We thought this piece of her story would be a fitting way to introduce our series on Christianity and the Arts. 
The doctrines of systematic theology are often caricatured (sometimes accurately) as cold and cerebral. We speak about beautiful things, but ironically, beauty seems to have little place in theology. But does Christian orthodoxy mean for us to ignore our senses in place of ivory-towered contemplation? In this series, Michael Horton, Justin Holcomb, Bob Hiller, and Walter Strickland each interview experts in architecture, art, and preaching to see if there is, indeed, a vital place for Christian art, or if it's better left on knick-knack shelves in department stores.
https://whitehorseinn.org/

title: Christianity and Liberalism 100 Years Later #shorts
description: *NEW SERIES* During the early 1920s, the ideas of Freud, Marx, and Nietzsche brought about the era of science and enlightenment, and liberalism was the next cultural move. This marked a new horizon for the church in America, but not necessarily for the better. In 1923, J. Gresham Machen‚Äôs seminal work, Christianity and Liberalism, was published, contrasting the modernist theological liberalism of his day with biblical Christianity. Arguing that liberalism couldn‚Äôt actually be called Christianity, he showed how the two differed in crucial areas. In this new White Horse Inn series, hosts Michael Horton, Justin Holcomb, Bob Hiller, and Walter Strickland revisit Machen‚Äôs work 100 years later, reflecting on its historic importance and relevance today as liberalism continues to creep into the church. title: "Christology is answering the sin problem." #shorts
description:
Many churches preach that your biggest problem is that you‚Äôre not living your best life now. Reformed theology provides a doctrine to help counter this wrong diagnosis of our true problem: total depravity. description:

title: Recovering Our Sanity ‚Äì How the Fear of God Conquers the Fears That Divide Us
description:
‚ÄúFear God‚Äù and ‚ÄúDo not be afraid‚Äù are two phrases that are often repeated in Scripture. Sadly, today we are living through an epidemic of fear. We‚Äôre afraid of everyone and everything it seems‚Ä¶. except God. 

In his new book, Recovering Our Sanity ‚Äì How the Fear of God Conquers the Fears That Divide Us, Dr. Michael Horton explores what the Scriptures say about fear, and how the fear of God, rightly applied, helps us overcome the barriers that prevent us from finding rest in His word. 

For a gift of $50 or more, you can request a copy of this book. Your support now will help us continue our work and reach more people with a message of joy, hope, and confidence found in the gospel. Get your copy here: https://whitehorseinn.org/fearofgod/

title: Christianity and Popular Culture: Understanding Our Time
description:
Churches in our time appear to be on a never-ending quest for contemporary relevance. In an attempt to attract larger numbers and compete in the marketplace of competing options, many churches throughout America have made their services more relevant, upbeat, and even entertaining.

But is this a wise course to take? Shouldn‚Äôt the church stand up for the timelessness of truth, rather than the timeliness of the trendy?

In our new collection, "Christianity and Popular Culture: Understanding Our Time," we discuss this and more, as we consider the effects that American pop culture has had on the church. This downloadable collection features 12 extended-length White Horse Inn shows and 5 Modern Reformation articles on the topic. It‚Äôs available to you for a gift of ANY AMOUNT. Get this offer today: https://whitehorseinn.org/popculture

title: Win the Person, Not the Argument - Abdu Murray
description:

As a proud Muslim, Abdu Murray enjoyed sparring with people of other faiths. But when he was eventually confronted with the evidence for Christ‚Äôs death and resurrection, he allowed that truth to be eclipsed by the losses he might suffer as a result of his conversion. After years of indecision, he eventually concluded that the Christian gospel was worth dying for. Abdu Murray now serves as the Senior Vice President of RZIM and is the author of Grand Central Question, Saving Truth, and most recently Seeing Jesus from the East, which he co-wrote with Ravi Zacharias. title: Justified - Dr. Michael Horton
description: The doctrine of justification is under attack.  Dr. Horton explains why this collection of essays is timely and relevant.  To purchase the book head here: http://www.whitehorseinn.org/justified

title: A Place for Weakness - Dr. Michael Horton
description:
The good news that God's Word proclaims is a recipe to use in times of disaster. That is to say, it comes as a relevant announcement only to those who are in trouble for one reason or another. A Place for Weakness, formerly titled Too Good to Be True, by award-winning Michael Horton, calls for more realism in facing life's challenges and a richer view of God and his purposes to match them.

Learn more about White Horse Inn: http://www.whitehorseinn.org/
